review:
Peersky Browser stands as a bold attempt to reclaim the decentralized web for the people, not the profit-driven gatekeepers! The project’s core mission—enabling native, gatewayless access to .eth domains and decentralized content—directly addresses the centralization crisis plaguing Ethereum’s user experience. By removing reliance on HTTP gateways like eth.limo, Peersky strikes at the heart of Web3’s most insidious contradiction: the dependence on centralized infrastructure for so-called decentralized content.

The application demonstrates a clear understanding of the technical and social challenges facing Ethereum. It identifies the lack of native ENS/IPFS resolution in mainstream browsers, the complexity of Web3 publishing, and the erosion of privacy as urgent problems. Peersky’s solution—local-first, peer-to-peer browsing with support for ENS, IPFS, and smart contract data—shows technical ingenuity and a commitment to user empowerment.

However, the application falls short in several critical areas demanded by our constitutional principles. There is a glaring lack of quantitative data: no user adoption metrics, no performance benchmarks, no evidence of impact on the Ethereum network. The roadmap is ambitious but vague, with no concrete milestones, timelines, or measurable outcomes. Sustainability is not addressed—there is no mention of a revenue model or long-term maintenance plan. While the project is open-source and community-oriented, there is no clear governance structure or plan for equitable participation, especially for underserved communities.

Peersky’s vision is inspiring, but inspiration alone does not build sustainable, equitable infrastructure. The people deserve evidence, transparency, and a plan for the long haul!

strengths.title: Direct Attack on Centralization
strengths.description: Peersky eliminates the need for centralized HTTP gateways, restoring true decentralization to ENS and IPFS content resolution. This is a powerful step toward reclaiming the web for the people.

strengths.title: Technical Innovation in User Experience
strengths.description: The browser’s native support for ENS, IPFS, and smart contract browsing (web3://) is a genuine leap forward in usability and privacy for decentralized web users.

strengths.title: Clear Alignment with Open-Source and Public Good Principles
strengths.description: Peersky is open-source, protocol-native, and explicitly designed to serve the collective rather than private interests.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Quantitative Evidence
weaknesses.description: The application provides no user adoption data, performance metrics, or measurable outcomes. There is no way to objectively assess the project’s impact or success.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Roadmap and Milestones
weaknesses.description: The roadmap is high-level and aspirational, lacking specific, time-bound milestones or deliverables. This undermines accountability and makes progress difficult to track.

weaknesses.title: No Sustainability or Revenue Model
weaknesses.description: There is no discussion of how the project will sustain itself beyond grant funding, nor any plan for long-term maintenance or community stewardship.

weaknesses.title: Missing Governance and Equity Plan
weaknesses.description: The application does not describe how decisions will be made, how the community will participate, or how the project will ensure equitable access and benefit, especially for marginalized groups.

changes.title: Provide Quantitative Metrics and Evidence
changes.description: Submit current user adoption numbers, performance benchmarks, and any available data on the browser’s impact. If unavailable, outline a plan for rigorous measurement and transparent reporting.

changes.title: Define a Concrete Roadmap with Milestones
changes.description: Break down the development plan into specific, time-bound milestones with clear deliverables. Include a timeline and criteria for success.

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainability and Revenue Model
changes.description: Describe how the project will be maintained and funded in the long term. Consider community funding, cooperative models, or other sustainable approaches.

changes.title: Establish a Governance and Equity Framework
changes.description: Detail how decisions will be made, how the community will be involved, and how the project will ensure equitable participation and benefit, especially for underserved populations.
